children.name: CA
children.message:
Salut !

Donc, ça marche. J'ai commandé et installé un xCarLink2 pour Toyota "Petit". C'est le connecteur qui est petit (2 rangées de 6 pinoches), regardez bien la photo du connecteur sur le site du vendeur avant d'acheter. Ne pas se tromper: Ne pas acheter celui avec le grand connecteur (et ne pas acheter non plus un modèle pour un autre constructeur). Le modèle de mon autoradio est W58824 (noté en façade). Je l'ai commandé sur Amazon, arrivé en 2 jours.

J'ai démonté l'autoradio existant en suivant les instructions qu'on trouve sur Internet, par ex:
http://www.carstereofaqs.co...
http://www.fitaudio.com/?Vi...
C'est vraiment facile: extraire les 2 joues en plastiques qui sont clipsées, dévisser les 4 vis de l'autoradio, et retirer la façade des molettes pour chauffage/ventilation qui est aussi clipsée. L'autoradio est aussi maintenu en-haut pas le plastique du tableau de bord. Il suffit de le soulever et de relever les 3 languettes. Pour remonter le tout, remettre d'abord la façade de ventilation, puis l'autoradio, puis les 2 joues. J'ai pris mon temps et ai mis moins d'une demi-heure. Attention de ne pas laisser tomber de vis dans le puits sans fond ! :)

J'ai connecté le cordon du xCarLink 2 à la place du connecteur 2×6 pinoches existant (d'où sort un fil jaune), à l'arrière de l'autoradio. Puis j'ai passé le cordon du xCarLink 2 jusque dans la boîte à gants. Pour ouvrir complètement la boîte à gant, il faut savoir que de chaque côté, il y a une butée qui l'empêche de s'ouvrir complètement. Donc, un côté à la fois, il faut presser sur le côté de la boîte à gants avec le pouce pour que la butée passe à côté, et tirer en pliant légèrement la boîte à gants (aucun risque).

Ensuite j'ai quand même fait le test et mis l'autoradio en marche pour être sûr avant de tout remonter. Ça fonctionne bien. Le son est très bon, meilleur que mon émetteur FM sur prise allume-cigare ! On utilise donc les commandes comme s'il s'agissait d'un chargeur de CDs. On a 12 CDs virtuels avec chacun 99 pistes disponibles. Ça, c'est ce que dit le manuel. Il faut créer 12 dossiers à la racine de la carte SD ou de la clé USB, chacun nommé "CD01" à "CD12", avec des pistes dedans. Ma carte SD n'est pas structurée de la sorte, mais a des pistes à la racine, ainsi qu'un dossier "New", et d'autres pistes à l'intérieur. Ça marche pourtant très bien. On a donc les fonctions d'un lecteur CD, avec lecture répétée, aléatoire, navigation par dossier, changement de "CD", sauf que c'est sur mémoire flash. Ça remplace le lecteur CD livré avec la voiture (je ne m'en servais plus depuis belle lurette de toutes façons).

Je n'ai pas commandé la fonctionnalité Bluetooth car elle ne répond pas à mes attentes. C'est en fait un kit mains-libres, mais moi ce que j'aurais voulu c'est connecter un casque Bluetooth avec réduction active de bruit (Bose QuickComfort 35) au xCarLink 2 pour écouter la musique en conduisant sur de longs trajets (sans entendre le bruit du moteur). Cette utilisation n'est pas possible avec le xCarLink 2. Donc pour ce cas de figure, j'utiliserai mon téléphone portable et j'enverrai la musique vers mon casque via Bluetooth.

Autre chose: les noms des pistes peuvent s'afficher, mais seulement si les MP3 tags sont présents sur le fichier MP3, apparemment. Je pense que je vais mettre ce petit appareil dans une chaussette pour limiter les vibrations en roulant (l'électronique ça aime pas les vibrations). J'ai payé le xCarLink 2 sur Amazon €65. Très satisfait de mon achat !

Acleis1.message: Merci pour l'article ! Sur la dernière photo (mise à jour juillet 2016), à quoi sert le condensateur ? Et la bobine ?

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Sur la photo de la carte, on voit en blanc l'ESP-201 (seule ESP-201 que je possède et je n'en achèterai pas d'autre). À gauche les deux résistances et le jumper servent à configurer l'ESP en mode "flash" ou "exécution".
À droite de l'ESP-201, le composant orange est un fusible automatique (là c'est un modèle 3 ampères, si ma mémoire est bonne, ce qui est une valeur un peu trop forte pour être utile).
En dessous du connecteur d'alim, on voit deux diodes silicium type 1N4004 qui servent à redresser la tension d'alim (qui est du 24V AC). Elles sont en série afin d'abaisser un peu la tension perçue par le module buck (qui n'est pas la référence mentionnée dans l'article, mais qui dans le montage final est ce module : http://www.ebay.com/itm/281... ). Le buck ne tolère que 24V à son entrée donc j'ai jugé intéressant d'avoir 2*0.7V de "voltage drop" avant.
Il y a également une zener dont j'avoue ne pas trop me souvenir de l'utilité, mais vu comme elle est câblée je pense que c'est une zener 3.3V que j'ai mis là pour garantir la stabilité de la sortie. C'est probablement inutile voire nuisible.
Le condensateur sert à stabiliser la tension de sortie. Flasher l'ESP8266 génère des pics de consommation de courant qui posent souvent problème, donc le condensateur est nécessaire.
J'ignore ce que vous appelez "bobine". Si vous voulez parler de celle qui est montée sur la circuit vertical, c'est un des composants du module buck utilisé http://www.ebay.com/itm/281...

BabymonEN.name: colin willcocks
BabymonEN.message: Found this project code very useful - Thank You. Trying to make a project similar to this using the ESP8266-12F with 8 channels of 24bit 48 kHz audio.

children.name: sven337
children.message:
8 channels, 24bit, 48kHz? I don't believe that this will be possible without specialized external chips... and even then...
I'm curious to know what architecture you have in mind?

children.name: colin willcocks
children.message: I have 4 x PCM1803 A/D converters, will use one as master and 3 as slave, into a PIC32 to multiplex the 4 data streams into 256 byte block "ADAT" format (12Mbps), and encode to NRZI (6Mbps), then to the ESP8266 via SPI. I am not sure the ESP8266 SPI is capable of that rate, and may have to look at other WiFi modules. Looking to do lowest latency audio for live use, so fancy data compression methods are not desirable which require too much buffering. The other end will be another ESP8266 with 4 x PCM1770 D/A. The ESP8266 will only be used to push data through end to as quickly as possible, probably using UDP, not sure if stripping unnecessary parts of the TCP/IP stack will help... I am open to suggestions :-)

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Unless I'm mistaken your data stream will be 8.79Mbps. NRZI is not a compression scheme, so how do you get down to 6Mbps?
Transmitting 9Mbps from the PIC to the ESP8266 via SPI shouldn't be too hard. I'm not sure if the ESP8266 will be able to push 9Mbps over wifi, however, especially if you use small packets to reduce latency. Think hard about your latency requirements, because it would be best to send ~1.5kB packets instead of 256 bytes.

(It's not terribly useful, but you may want to consider data compression methods at the scale of one audio packet. The delta7 thing I'm describing (which won't apply to you) is simple and provides some benefits. Even a RLE scheme might help. If latency is really sensitive I think you should be able to hide it entirely by doing it on the fly when you acquire data. My code does it at packet send time because it was easier to implement, but it's not required.)

I would advise testing the ESP8266 throughput first, to be sure that it can sustain the kind of transfer rates that you seek. ~1MB/s is in the realm of high bandwidth operation, which I (and the community in general, I believe) have little practical experience with.

Another thing comes to mind, but you're probably more experienced with analog circuitry than I am: the ESP8266 is susceptible to inducing a lot of noise. Don't run your analog circuitry next to the antenna or power wires, and decouple *really* well.

BabymonEN.name: Jean Taeymans
BabymonEN.message:
Hi,

Very interesting project, much in line with what I am trying to build, i.e. a device to remote a RF transceiver over a LAN/WAN.
I managed to modify your code to my purpose (8ks/s 16bit sound) in less than a few hours using the Arduino IDE, got a tone streaming on my Ubuntu laptop. The power of the ESP8266 is impressive, it does not give a crimp at 16 packets/s (128kb/s), great for a thing that costs less than 5€.

When I tried to use TCP i.s.o. UDP it didn't work though, apparently the use of the Timer1 (as the interrupt source for the sampling) is incompatible with Arduino's WiFiServer library. I suspect that the Timer1 is used elsewhere for the TCP routines.
Any thoughts about that ? Any other timers available ? Can you please point me to the relevant documentation (the ERSP8266 is the worst documented microprocessor I have ever encountered, the Arduino library is barely better).

All the best and thanks on beforehand.

children.name: sven337
children.message:
Hi,
I'm glad my code was useful to someone else. I didn't have a 16bit ADC so I went for 12bit, and raised the sampling frequency to "compensate". Sound quality is good but not great -- for a baby monitor it's quite fine.

I'm not aware of the limitation you are mentioning, but I have 0 previous experience using TCP on the ESP8266. I just don't see the point of TCP for an audio streaming application (unless it's not realtime). It's true that if Timer1 is used for TCP routines, it may interfere with my code. I haven't found evidence that it was used for TCP, but then again I don't know how it's implemented.

You might be able to use Timer0. I'm curious to hear about your results with that.
As for "documentation", what I use are the sources of esp8266-Arduino, some of the Espressif-published documents, their example code with the SDK package, and disassembling the SDK & ROM. As MCUs goes, the ESP8266 is largely undocumented, at least officially. I think they do have a document covering timers and interrupts, though.

children.name: Jean Taeymans
children.message:
Hi again,

Many thanks for your quick response.

I tried "Timer0" i.s.o. "Timer1", but this one gives a "not defined" compilation error (as do "Timer2" or "Timer3"). I am using the same includes as you do. With "Timer1" the sketch compiles and loads, a few seconds after the setup part the following message comes via the serial port:
ets Jan 8 2013,rst cause:4, boot mode:(1,7)
wdt reset
The watchdog seems to be triggered even before any TCP client was available/connected.
The simple telnet example provided with the Arduino ESP8266 IDE compiles and works, adding it to the previous sketch with the UDP streaming (and mutatis mutandi) will make it to crash. Removing the Timer1 setup part will make it work again.

To be honest, the little trials I did so far with UDP were not with a proper ADC, the ESP-01 module I currently use does not have the SPI brough out on the pins. I just synthesized, DDS fashion, a simple square wave instead. For my project I will use the same 12bit ADC as you as it is a fair compromise between price, ease of use and resolution. I have some experience with this component and 65..70dB SNR is quite enough for my purpose. Also I suspect that there are no 16bit ADC on the market with a SPI interface capable say 10ks/s. Most of the audio codecs have a I2S interface, which is alledgedly also available on the ESP8266 but is even less documented.
I grant you that UDP is probably sufficient for sound transfer over a LAN/WAN, nothing can be done with late packets anyhow.
This will however not help me since I need a rather reliable control channel for the RF tranceiver itself. Actually something like telenet at 9600 baud, only a few packets/s bidirectional. I was hoping to combine both functions into the same ESP8266 chip.

Many thanks again and all the best.

children.name: sven337
children.message:
I don't think that timer0 will be usable anyway, but timer1 definitely should work, even with TCP. If you're having issues, something must be wrong in your code elsewhere. Can you share it?
Maybe start from my code and modify it?

You're right that 16bit ADCs that can do 10 or 20ks/s are hard to find (or at least they're not cheap). I2S works on the ESP8266, and you even get DMA, so better performance. It is, however, tricky to use correctly, and the existing projects that make use of it are unfortunately very hard to read (cnlohr I'm looking at you).

children.name: Jean Taeymans
children.message:
Hi again,

Of course I'll share the sketch, I try to upload it with this message. Many thanks for the offer to look at it.
As you will apreciate, I took your code "xmit.ino" and more or less deleted everything that I didn't need. I increased the adc_buffer up to 1 second worth of sound (useless with UDP, but handy with TCP). children.name: sven337
children.message:
Quoting from the datasheet:
"The MCP3201 device provides a single pseudo-differential input. The IN+ input can range from IN- to VREF
(VREF+ IN-). The IN- input is limited to ±100 mV from the VSS
rail. The IN- input can be used to cancel small signal common-mode noise which is present on both the IN+ and IN- inputs."

So IN- goes to GND.

IP_target_PC was a debugging target (a computer with netcat listening). I used that to get waveforms from the transmitter and analyze them; and to test the compression rates.

Note, the way you've hooked up the LM358P isn't going to work. You need to use it as an inverting amplifier with a bias voltage of Vcc/2 applied to the positive input (I'm writing this from memory). See https://lowvoltage.wordpres... which I followed.

children.name: sven337
children.message:
It looks like I'm using a 15x amplification on the LM358.
If you have an oscilloscope, look at the signal at the input and output of the LM358 to see if it looks like what you want. It should be centered on Vcc/2 and vary between 0 and Vcc as you speak. If you do *not* have a scope, things are more difficult.

Do you get values on the serial monitor that look like they span a wide enough range? If you don't, then you're probably not listening to the microphone and just looking at noise.

The .c files are for testing on the computer. You can ignore them. The code that runs on the ESP8266 devices is in the xmit/ and recv/ directories.
xmit already implements a "send nothing when below threshold" logic
https://github.com/sven337/...
https://github.com/sven337/...
How it works is covered, briefly, in the article

https://perso.aquilenet.fr/...

Oh, and you can send UDP control packets to the transmitter to alter its behavior. https://github.com/sven337/...
"sendnow" and "threshold" commands are relevant to what you're trying to achieve.

What I would suggest if you do *not* have a scope is to make the transmitter always transmit, then receive the sample locally (you can use my udpserver.c), and open them in audacity as a raw file. It's a bit tricky to get the right parameters for the import, but then you can look at the waveform.
